turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: My name is Gina!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: It's a letter from the school . . . from Miss Stewart.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: What does old Stew want?

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: She says the standard of your work is slipping. At this rate she doesn't think you'll get School Certificate.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Who cares!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I care . . . your father cares . . . we want you to have a good education.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I'm educating myself!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: You're failing English . . . you used to be top of the class- PAULINE I'm doing my own writing!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: snatches up an exercise book from a large pile.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: These stories are not going to get you School Certificate! You don't seriously think anyone's going to publish them?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: What do you know? You wouldn't know the first thing about writing. You're the most ignorant person I've ever met!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: is very angry.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: You're rude . . . rude and insolent! I don't see why I should keep a horrid child like you at school a minute longer.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I don't wanna be in bloody school!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: All right! You go out there and get a job and you damn well pay your own way!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I'm bloody dressing as fast as I can, for God's sake!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Open this door!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: The Hulmes will look after me. They want me to live with them!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Don't be so ridiculous. You're our daughter, you belong here with us.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I belong with Deborah! We're going to South Africa!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: You're not going anywhere. You're 15 years old!!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: You have to let me go!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: stands and walks toward the door.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I felt thoroughly depressed and even quite seriously considered committing suicide. Life seems so much not worth the living, death such an easy way out.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Love, you can still write to each other.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I bet he pitches a tent in the middle of their bedroom, and they have to pretend to be on some mountain!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: That's enough, Yvonne!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: You have it.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Oh, no. I'm watching my figure.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Look, Mother!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: looks down at the ground in front of her.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: And so, in a blazing fury, Charles runs Lancelot Trelawney through with his sword . . . leaving Deborah free to accept Charles's proposal of marriage!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: and HERBERT exchange a glance. HONORA smiles at Juliet.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I've heard your mother on 3YA. The Woman's Session has lots of lively debate.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Well, actually, Mummy's left that programme now . . she's far too busy with The Marriage Guidance Council.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I wouldn't want my private business being discussed with a complete stranger!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Oh, no . . . Mummy's awfully good at it.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm so happy to see you!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: hurries over.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: It's best not to get too close. Juliet's still not a hundred percent. Hello, Juliet! We've bought you some fruit.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Thank you so much!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: That's coming along well!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm the Matron's favourite patient and she's shown me her special stitch!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm saving them for a rainy day.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: gives her a sympathetic look.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I know it's hard for you being in here, but it is for the good of your health.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: They sent me off to the Bahamas "for the good of my health." They sent me to the Bay of bloody Islands "for the good of my health."

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: looks startled at the outburst.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mrs. Rieper. I'm feeling quite fatigued.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: We don't want to tire you out, dear.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: stands and picks up her handbag. Pauline stands and Juliet grabs her hand.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Can't you stay a bit longer, Paul?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Hello!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Hello, Juliet. Juliet take off her jacket.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Oh-what a nice outfit!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Thank you. I bought it especially, Mrs. Rieper.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: is bending down, pulling a tray of sausage rolls into the oven. Both girls look at HONORA silently.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: turns around and Juliet presents her with a brown paper bag.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Fruit.

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: Oh! I'll pop them in a bowl.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: But you're not fat, Mrs. Rieper!

turns.speaker: HONORA
turns.text: I put on a lot of weight over Christmas.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Mummy!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Mummy!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: She's terribly hurt . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Somebody's got to help us!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: 0h, God . . . I'm so sorry!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: It doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Of course it matters! It's Mario!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I think I'm dying . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Don't . . . please! Please, don't!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I wish James would do a religious picture . . . he'd be perfect as Jesus!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Daddy says the Bible's a load of bunkum!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: But, we're all going to Heaven!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I'm not! I'm going to the Fourth World! It's like Heaven, only better because there aren't any Christians.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: James will be there . . . and Mario! Only they'll be saints.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Saint Mario!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: To be known as He!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: He . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Him.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Him . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: This.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: This . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: That.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: That . . .

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: He flings open the door and launches himself at the bed, ravishing her!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: God, yes!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: It's so beautiful!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: What???

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I shall call him Diello.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: You're such an incredible woman.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I couldn't have done it without you, Charles.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: You'll never guess what's happened!!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: What??

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: John has fallen in love with me!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: That idiot boarder?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: How do you know? Did he tell you?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Well . . . no. But it's so obvious.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I think I'm going crazy.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: No, you're not, Gina-it's everybody else who is bonkers!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Let's go overseas . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: You mean travel by ourselves?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Stay still or they'll be blurry . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Hurry up! I'm freezing!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Just a couple more . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I know, I'll lean forward and show more cleavage!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I'm sure they'll notice things missing.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: They'll blame the bloody housekeeper. She nicks stuff all the times!

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: This lot's got to be worth 50 quid!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I can try my father's safe. I'm sure I can get the keys to his office.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: That's great! We'll have the fare in no time!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I thought he was supposed to be terribly ill.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: That was what we were led to believe . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Poor Mother was completely taken in.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Do you think Bloody Bill's trying to get into her draws?

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Too right . . . but he doesn't have a show! Nobody gets into Mother's draws except Daddy!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Poor Father . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Don't worry, Gina! Mummy and Daddy love each other.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: But that's not true! I've got one.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I need my sodding parents' consent.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I'm coming with you.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Yes . . .

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I know what to do about mother.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Mummy!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Mummy!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Let's go upstairs, Deborah. I wrote the last 10 pages of my opera last night.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: All right, then.

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: It's a three-act story with a tragic end.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Your mother is a rather miserable woman . . . isn't she?

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: I thought for hours about whether Carmelita should accept Bernard's marriage proposal . . .

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: I think she knows what's going to happen . . . she doesn't appear to bear us any grudge!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Bye, Dad.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Goodbye, Mr. Rieper.

turns.speaker: JULIET
turns.text: Isn't it beautiful!

turns.speaker: PAULINE
turns.text: Let's go for a walk down here . . . come on, Mummy!

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Are you a dream too?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Still hallucinating as well. Hmm...

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What just happened to me anyway? It looked like a dream but it felt like reality.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: It's the morphine Trevor. You're on so much of it, you could be asleep and dreaming even with your eyes wide open.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Where's Kirsty? Where's my wife?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Your wife...?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What's happening to me? What are you doing?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: You came in for your EEG. You fell asleep and well, I took the liberty of...I'm sorry. You looked like a wreck Trevor.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Well? What do you say Trevor? Que pasa?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Let me see. Oh yeah. My head feels like it's going through a meat grinder. I'm not sure if I'm dreaming or...

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: That `poor me' attitude doesn't suit you Trevor. Listen, I don't mean to sound like Pollyanna but things could be worse. There's one good thing about coming so near to the end of ones life. Everything is new and exciting, like your seeing it for the first time. You might see things a litlle differently from now on.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Your insight is enlightening.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: No wisdom, no insight, no plan.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Allison? Why can't remember what happened to my wife? Is it something I'm on that's... that's making me forget?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Easy there Trevor. You need to relax.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: No I need to remember. Look whatever it is take me off it. I can handle pain. I can't handle not knowing...

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: You need to get better first Trevor. Way better.  It's okay to miss somebody. It's okay to still love someone after they're gone. But you've got to quit blaming yourself okay...? Okay?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: These hallucinations I'm having. I think they're more like memories coming back to me in a strange way.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Well that's not necessarily a bad thing is it?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: If they're blocked memories... I'm starting to realize the reason why I blocked them out. Allison I think I really... screwed everything up.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Shh. Don't blame yourself Trevor. Please.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I miss her. I miss my wife.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Well Trevor? What have you got to say for yourself? Que pasa?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Allison we have GOT to talk about this medication you've got me on.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: I'm all over it.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: You're one tough cookie, Trevor Gooding. You keep coming back to your corner for a quick fix up then go right back out into the ring for another round.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Some call it resilience. Others, stupidity.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Of course, yes.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: The way you just looked at me...

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: I know, my bedside manner's horrendous.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: So, I'm done. Thats it for today?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: All finished.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Hint. It's not a geographical location.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: I'm stumped.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: It's inside a moving car.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Bull...

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I've got numbers to back me up. Over the course of one year more Americans die in car accidents than did during the entire span of World War II.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Okay so... what's the safest place?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Millions of people around the world get on busses every day. When was the last time you heard of anybody anywhere dying on a public transit bus?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Okay Mr. Statistics I've got one for you. What's the most common cause of death for adults over the age of eighteen?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Please. Heart attack. That was easy street.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Second most common?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Skin cancer.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Eighty third most common.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Pitbull attacks.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: You just made that up.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: We startred off to be. She was, I guess I was. I just sort of....butchered up the relationship somehow.  Bad choice of words.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: I understand, I think. Other women?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Yeah. It's like I was a different guy then I am today. I can't remember that guy. I see these women, they think I'm someone else, and I'm not that guy anymore. I'm not sure who Kristy knew.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: You were unfaithful, it sounds like your confessing.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I did more then that.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Lucky for us these chairs happened to be here.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Oh I knew about the chairs already. This is where the emphysema patients come to sneak cigarettes.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Don't tell me. Kirsty used to smoke?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: No. She just would have loved it up here... Allison when I was under... did I ever talk?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Sure plenty of times.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Trevor if someone is talking from a sleep state they are obviously dreaming. So practically everything say is going to sound strange.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Did I ever talk about the accident?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Did I ever talk about Kirsty?

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: No. But at one point you did repeat something though. A phrase. You must have been having this recurring dream, you just kept saying this one thing over and over

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What was it?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: If it makes you feel better that took every ounce of self control I had. Trevor, I never date patients.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I understand... I won't-

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: No you don't understand. That's why I've been fighting to get you better. So you wouldn't be a patient anymore.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Why didn't you tell me sooner? I would have switched doctors!

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Just get better okay?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Allison I think I did some very, very bad things. I mean very bad.

turns.speaker: ALLISON
turns.text: Trevor things like this happen to people who experience temporary memory loss. Everybody does things they regret. You just couldn't remember doing these things and now you are so it's a shock to the system. I'm telling you. You will never get better if you keep blaming yourself for your wife's death.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Maybe I wasn't responsible for the car accident...

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Trevor what is the metric probability of you getting any work done at all today?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Hey Bret. Christ, my head feels like a split coconut.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Dude there is a track on the carpet between here and the bathroom. It was made by your ass. You've been dragging it all fucking week. What happened to you yesterday?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Give me a break. I checked back into the hospital- amongst other things.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Hospital? You haven't been to the hospital since uh...

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Since what?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Look never mind. Just get some numbers going- any numbers at all will due. The hills have eyes remember?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Must be nice.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Getting paid for doing shit.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: The boss won't notice me doing a bad job because I'm not. Even if the boss thought I was slacking I'd know right away.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Yeah, how's that?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I have my connections

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Really? Do tell.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Gwen.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: GWEN?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I crap you not. She was all over me yesterday in the break room. And she was a total machine last night too.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: You were supposed to have a date with Gwen last night? GWEN DEARDON? The supervisor?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Serious as a heart attack my friend. I think she literally fucked me brains out.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Hey if you're not doing anything I'd like to buy you a beer after work. Be just like old times.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What's the occasion?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: I quit. Today's my last day.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: I've got a better offer. More time off. A sort of career shift, more in the engineering line of work.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: How much time off?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: As much as he feels like. Its a much more pleasurable line of work.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: So you're just packing it up just like that?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Almost that fast. I got a few loose ends to tie up first. Came into a shitload of money recently. I've always wanted to go to take a trip. We're just gonna walk into the airport and decide right then and there.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Yeah? You and who else?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Someone special.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Bret... what the fuck...?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: Tonight was supposed to be the night, Trevor. Remember? I couldn't believe you went through five dart games and didn't even joke about it.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Bret. What the hell is going on?

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: We were gonna be millionaires you said. Nobody'd suspect a thing. I had never even met her. No connection. Then you went and had that fucking car accident.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Bret you are making no sense whatsoever.

turns.speaker: BRET
turns.text: I followed her Trevor. I got to know her life. And what a boring one it was. Six a.m. gym, nine a.m. trendy coffee shop, noon bookstore, one soap operas, four o'clock news, five wait for Trevor to come home. And wait and wait and wait. Nine o'clock get ready for bed.

turns.speaker: DR. AMBROSE
turns.text: Hello I'm Dr...

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Ambrose. I know.

turns.speaker: DR. AMBROSE
turns.text: Have we met?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I've been in here before.

turns.speaker: DR. AMBROSE
turns.text: Take no offense Trevor. I see many patients a day and have an awful memory.

turns.speaker: DR. AMBROSE
turns.text: Why don't you relax for the next couple of hours? Barring any relapses you should be able to go home after that.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Where's Allison?

turns.speaker: DR. AMBROSE
turns.text: Who's Allison?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Allison Dormere. Your intern.

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: What did you just say?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I said she's been missing for-

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: No. No you said HER BODY's been missing.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What's the difference?

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: Last time anybody saw this woman she was alive. You seem to certain she's dead.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: I saw her drowning inside the car, detective.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: You could say that.

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: Zero's a number right?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: As in one minus one equals zero yes. Where are you going with this?

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: How many zeros was your wife worth?

turns.speaker: GIVENS
turns.text: Now I want you to tell me what you remember happening- in your own words- exactly the way you told Detective Lange. But this time I want you to make one small adjustment.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: Come on speak up, Gooding, I'm trying to run a business here. I can't have people flipping out in the break room when they should be slaving away at their desks.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Sorry I just kind of... spaced for a second there.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: Get back here, junior bean counter. This is your supervisor speaking.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Please, Gwen. You're- you're all over me.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: How do you think you got this job, cock?  Mmm. I'm still tingling all over from our little midnight swim.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: What's wrong, Trev?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Nothing, look. Gwen I really like you-

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: And it shows. Least it did last night at the quarry. In a big way.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: YOU'RE giving ME a speeding ticket? Mr. Mario Andretti himself?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Gwen, my wife's dead.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: Oh I see. That again. Trevor? I realize it must be hard. But Christ how long does it take someone to move on?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: That was cold...

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: No, making another woman compete with someone who's been dead eight months. That's cold.

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: Good boy.  Where's is it?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GWEN
turns.text: Our little toy. You usually have it up and running by now.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Do I really want to know what you're talking about?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Twenty one. Why do we have to do this now Kirsty?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Shut up and play darling. Your turn.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Five hundred ninety two thousand seven hundred and four.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Uh... eighty two?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Eighty four.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You win! Okay pull over.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: But... I thought...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: If what I've heard is true this could be the last time for a long long time. Besides we've got a whole seven minutes before the next one. Clock's ticking. Tick-tock...

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What isn't wrong? Why are you doing this anyway?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I'm... I'm doing a very special thing here. And you can't even ... respond?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Just concentrate on the task at hand please. Listen to me. You should be giving ME this lecture.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You've been cheating on me haven't you?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Yes I had a quickie with the neighbor during your last contraction.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Roughly two thirds of married men who cheat start during the eighth month of their wives' first pregnancy.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Oh my God. It's coming out.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: THE BABY IS COMING OUT! I CAN FEEL IT! SONOFABITCH IT HURTS!! AAAGGGGHHH!!!

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: OH MY GOD TREVOR! It hurts!!  oh my God, Oh my God. Trevor, It's coming out.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: This isn't happening.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: How does feel to be Mr. Kirsty Hughes for a whole year.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: In a word? Lucrative.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: The best business decision if you ever made I'll bet.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Enjoyable too. The merger never even felt work for one second.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: You know what the family lawyer told me one our wedding day?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Never to put you in my will.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Really? Why?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: But you had more wisdom than to listen to a false prophet

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: There is no wisdom, no insight, no plan

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: And besides, I thought, to hell with it... it's okay if you only married me for my money.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Really, why's that?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: I only married you for your body.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Happy Anniversary, Mrs. Gooding.

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: For me? Trevor! How romantic! Come here, you.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Kirsty... Kirsty?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: It's okay it was just a nightmare that's all.

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: You're alive...

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Yes. Now go back to sleep. You're driving the rest of the way to gramma's remember?

turns.speaker: KIRSTY
turns.text: Trevor I've decided we have got to agree on a name before we reach my mother's. This poor kid's going to be starting preschool as student x if we don't make up our minds. So, I've been thinking, what about Daisy?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: It's perfect.

turns.speaker: LANGE
turns.text: Thanks for coming down Mr. Gooding. Has your head healed okay by now?

turns.speaker: TREVOR
turns.text: Where's my wife?

turns.speaker: LANGE
turns.text: Okay then. Here's the scoop.
